channel.title: ഇന്നത്തെ ചിന്താവിഷയം | Thoughts of the Day

item.description:
• https://pluralistic.net/2021/05/09/the-memex-method/
    • Revisited the whole reason I decided to resurrect this blog.
    • Feels right to do this before the new year starts rather than during or with the new year. I feel like its takes the pressure out from the day.

  • https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/JBR6AF9Gusv4u6Fwo/laziness-death-spirals?utm_source=pocket_shared
    • A first person account of laziness and procrastination that really resonated with me.
    • I realized that I had also stumbled upon some of the strategies listed in this essay in my lifelong battle with procrastination and poor attention/focus.

• https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2024/12/trust-issues-in-ai.html
    • Inisightful piece into the fundamental trust deficit that exists between human users and all modern LLM based AI's
    • I liked the fact that they directly called out Meta and LLama for pretending to be "open source" AI without really revealing anything about the training data set.

  • https://ludic.mataroa.blog/blog/you-must-read-at-least-one-book-to-ride/
    • Is this author me ? Was just taken aback by a combination of references to Malaysia and Christopher Hitchens.
    • I echo the author's sentiment that most people have not even read one book that centers around their chosen profession.

• https://frontline.thehindu.com/environment/bhopal-1984-gas-leak-emblematic-india-environmental-degradation-great-nicobar-indian-bustard/article68968130.ece
    • In Nehru's Discovery of India, he talks about discussing with villagers what their idea of India is, especially when he was welcomed with chants of "Bharath Mata Ki Jai" (Victory to Mother India).
    • Nehru goes on to expand on this and frames "India" as the sum total of all natural features of the land we as a people inhibit. Including forests, rivers, mountains and associated fauna. According to him that is the "Mother India" that we hope will be victorious in time.
    • This is further enshrined in the constitution as the 7th fundamental duty of every citizen of India.
      To protect and improve the natural environment including forests, lakes, rivers, wildlife and to have compassion for living creatures;
    • Its a pity that the mother India willed into existence as part of the freedom struggle is being neglected and cut up in the name of "development".

  • https://blog.samaltman.com/productivity
    • 6 year old blog post I chanced upon from Sam Altman about his approach to productivity.
    • I like the general advice about needing to pivot from looking out for your ideal productivity setup and tweaking it ad-nauseam to just simply focus on worrying about whether you are working on the right items.
    • Paper based lists and note-taking FTW.

• https://www.thenation.com/article/culture/kendrick-lamar-butterfly-effect-book-excerpt/
    • I spent a non-trivial amount of time diving into the rabbit hole i.e Kendrick Lamar's lyrical prowess over the past week.
    • It all started when I listened to this comedy material from Josh Johnson
    • I subsequently looked up the Kendrick Lamar song "Not like us" and found it to be an absolute banger with top tier writing.
    • It'll take multiple hours to look up all the various disses and backstories behind each line of it. As a fan of good writing(in general), I consider it to be master class which led to more trawling.
    • That's when I came across this book excerpt about his "poetic awakening".

  • https://arstechnica.com/ai/2024/12/2024-the-year-ai-drove-everyone-crazy/
    • Good collection of AI fails?! from the past calendar year.
    • Its a good way to remember that these LLM's are not infallible and can break in surprising ways. Sometimes so surprising that even their developers might need a minute or two to actually even begin to comprehend what actually went down.

• http://thetimes.com/article/why-conversations-are-better-with-four-people-zhxbsg06s?utm_source=pocket_shared
    • Robin Dunbar (of "Dunbar's number" fame) postulates that 4 is the upper limit of people for having a productive conversation
    • When I think back to group conversations I've participated in the recent past, anecdotally, this tracks.
    • This might also have broader implications to figuring out meeting audiences at work

  • http://jacobin.com/2024/12/jordan-peterson-bible-conservatives-review?utm_source=pocket_shared
    • I personally have a complicated relationship with the writings of Jordan Peterson.
    • I have spent non-trivial amount of time watching his old lectures that are still up on youtube. I also own a paperback copy of his "12 rules for life : An antidote to chaos".
    • Like the Jacobin reviewer I too found that as far as self-help books go, it wasn't too terrible and was an interesting spin.
    • I initially found JP to be a knowledgeable figure (especially as a psychologist) albeit with a very pronounced western/euro-centric bias of history.
    • I also personally discovered his approach to tackling life problems via writing to be very useful advice.
    • To me his downfall started with his ludicrous attempt at debating communism against Slavoj Zizek where JP appeared to be horribly underprepared and out of his league.
    • It has been disappointing and disheartening to watch him turn from an interesting voice to a full-fledged right-wing soap box.
    • I have two pet theories that explain this.
      • 1. Is that he (like many other public figures) got locked into a distorted bubble by the social media feed he consumes.
      • 2. (This qualifies as a conspiracy theory) That he's being bankrolled by right wing deep pockets.

• https://www.malaymail.com/news/malaysia/2024/12/27/pm-anwar-mourns-loss-of-cherished-friend-former-indian-premier-manmohan-singh/161239
    • I did not know of this friendship between MMS and DSAI
    • I had read The Accidental Prime Minister on the cusp of MMS exiting as PM and Modi entering power.
    • Even in a book that his political opponents used as a source of ammunition to attack him, my impression was that MMS was an honest thoughtful administrator and may as well have been one of the better PM's in a generation or two.
    • The personal example that DSAI revealed just adds on to that impression.
    • May he rest in peace

  • http://wired.com/story/stopped-using-passwords-passkeys?FINANCEBUZZ-2024_12_27=&category=fascinating_stories&position=2&scheduled_corpus_item_id=97ad3d85-bd2c-4a2e-ad2e-308322f310c4&sponsored=0&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.wired.com%2Fstory%2Fstopped-using-passwords-passkeys%2F&utm_source=pocket_shared
    • I still have not switched any of my accounts from traditional password + MFA to passkeys yet.
    • Only my work Microsoft account has gone fully passwordless.
    • I need to spend some time researching fully free software based solutions for it.
    • I also need to study the end-to-end implementation lifecycle so that I can gauge accurately as to whether I should nudge my clients to start supporting passkeys in their platforms.

  • https://minds.md/zakirullin/cognitive?utm_source=pocket_shared
    • Good primer on taking into account the impact of cognitive load when it comes to system design.
    • I found the advice here to be especially relevant in today's world when everyone defaults to a complex microservice architecture.
    • The article rightly points out that it seems like no one learned any lessons from the legendary Torvalds-Tanenbaum flamewar
    • Usually advice about cognitive load more or less boils down to generic science based platitudes like keeping arguments of a function to 7 +/- 2 etc.
    • I liked that the piece delved deeper into other aspects of system design like variable naming, inheritance, service boundaries etc.

• http://bcs.org/articles-opinion-and-research/does-current-ai-represent-a-dead-end?utm_source=pocket_shared
    • This aligns with my personal observation around various AI tools that have seeped into my workflow.
    • Even tools like Office 365 Copilot, whose advertised capabilities should be a slam dunk sell for any knowledge worker like me, I found that I stopped trusting them pretty fast because I found them to be unreliable compared to a standard search.
    • Only in specific corner cases like summarization etc. did I get some benefit from it.
    • This article makes a good point by linking trust in AI systems to properties like compositional-ity to better frame perceived lack of trust in these systems.

  • http://daringfireball.net/2024/12/openai_unimaginable
    • Interesting piece of John Gruber who draws parallels between OpenAI and Netscape before the dot-com boom
    • Its becoming increasingly clear that OpenAI does not have a moat.

  • http://prospect.org/infrastructure/transportation/2024-03-28-suicide-mission-boeing
    • Overview of how ageism(in addition to short term financialization) ruined one of the finest engineering firms of the 20th century
    • I learned that Boeing actually used to estimate that it takes 4 years for an engineer to become fully productive within the firm, thereby encouraging steady learning and building of loyal institutional knowledge.
    • The average years of experience amongst engineers in stable teams were between 15-20.

  • http://admiralcloudberg.medium.com/masks-smoke-and-mirrors-the-untold-story-of-egyptair-flight-804-42c788fcac2d
    • Riveting expose into the underlying mystery of the crash of Egypt Air Flight 804.

item.title: About
item.description:
What is this ?

This is a common place (web) notebook / blog. Refer here for a detailed explanation.

Who am I ?

Doesn't really matter.

How should I read this ?

You can explore at will, or subscribe over rss
